qas.question: What did two biologists point out in 1964?

answers.text: cases where two or more clines are distributed discordantly

qas.question: What gene distribution decreases as you move away from the equator in either direction?
What do the frequencies for the haplotype for beta-5 hemogoblin do from specific points in Africa?
To what profession do both Leonard Lieberman and Fatimah Linda Jackson belong?
What patterns of heterogeneity falsify any descriptions of population?

context: In 1964, the biologists Paul Ehrlich and Holm pointed out <a0_0>cases where two or more clines are distributed discordantly<a0_0/>—for example, <a1_0>melanin<a1_0/> is distributed in a decreasing pattern from the equator north and south; frequencies for the haplotype for beta-S hemoglobin, on the other hand, <a2_0>radiate<a2_0/> out of specific geographical points in Africa. As the <a3_0>anthropologists<a3_0/> Leonard Lieberman and Fatimah Linda Jackson observed, "<a4_0>Discordant<a4_0/> patterns of heterogeneity falsify any description of a population as if it were genotypically or even phenotypically homogeneous".
